awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Modeling, Analysis, and Control of the Spatio-temporal Dynamics of Swarm Robotic Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Massive populations, or swarms, of low-cost autonomous robots have the potential to collectively perform tasks over very large domains and time scales, succeeding even in the presence of failures, errors, and disturbances.  It is becoming feasible to create robotic swarms in practice due to ongoing advances in computing, sensing, actuation, power, control, and 3D printing technologies.  In recent years, the miniaturization of these technologies has led to many novel robot platforms for swarm applications, including micro aerial vehicles.  However, it remains a challenge to reliably control arbitrary numbers of such resource-constrained robots in unknown environments where global information and communication are limited or undependable.  This research project aims to overcome this challenge by developing a rigorous framework for the scalable control of robotic swarms in realistic environments.  The framework combines techniques from the fields of fluid dynamics, signal reconstruction, control theory, and optimization.  This work provides a theoretically grounded approach for automatically programming robotic swarms to perform a diverse set of tasks of wide benefit to society, including environmental monitoring and exploration, disaster recovery, security operations, and even biomedical imaging and targeted cancer therapies at the nanoscale.  
 
This project develops a formal methodology for analyzing and controlling the spatiotemporal dynamics of robotic swarms that are to be deployed in complex unknown environments. The designed robot control policies incorporate stochastic behaviors such as random encounters with environmental features and produce target collective behaviors within a specified degree of confidence. The confidence estimates are computed using a novel application of vortex methods, originally derived for fluid dynamic models and recently adapted to obtain continuum limits of discrete swarm models that incorporate pairwise interaction rules for maintenance of group structure. The control approach uses new computational algorithms for compressive sensing to reconstruct scalar environmental fields from sparse robot sensor data and to design efficient strategies for robot data collection.  The methodology is demonstrated with a case study on designing control policies for micro aerial vehicles that are tasked to pollinate a crop field.  Both computer models and testbed field experiments are used to validate theoretical predictions for the confidence estimates on system performance. Beyond robotics, the project provides analytical tools for a deeper understanding of the complex macroscopic behaviors of systems that can be represented with similar models, including non-well-mixed chemical reaction networks and natural swarms such as social insect colonies.

por.por_cntn:
Swarms of low-cost autonomous robots have the potential to collectively perform tasks of wide benefit to society over very large domains and time scales. Such tasks include environmental monitoring, exploration and mapping, automated pollination, disaster recovery, security operations, and even biomedical applications at the micro-nanoscale such as molecular imaging, targeted drug and gene delivery, therapeutics, and diagnostics. In recent years, many novel robot platforms such as micro aerial vehicles have been developed for swarm applications. However, it remains a challenge to reliably control large numbers of such resource-constrained robots in unknown environments where global information and communication are limited or unavailable.

This research project aimed to overcome this challenge by developing a rigorous framework for the scalable control of robotic swarms in realistic environments. The framework is based on a novel integration and application of techniques from the fields of fluid dynamics, control theory, and optimization. This work provides a theoretically grounded approach for automatically programming swarms of robots to perform mapping and coverage operations and to allocate themselves autonomously among a set of tasks. We validated our framework with computer simulations and through experiments with small, low-cost robots. The specific intellectual contributions and broader impacts of the project are described below.

We developed new analytical approaches to solve the inverse problem of robotic swarm control for distributed coverage tasks: defining a target metric of coverage activity and deriving robot controllers that provably achieve this objective. These approaches rely on the correspondence between continuum (ordinary or partial differential equation [ODE/PDE]) and discrete (individual-based) models of a robotic swarm. We estimated the error between these models for swarms whose spatiotemporal behavior is described by advection-diffusion-reaction (ADR) PDEs and applied these estimates to select swarm parameters that guarantee spatial coverage within specified bounds. This rigorous analysis, previously absent from work on control of stochastic multi-agent systems, provides a formal validation of novel "top-down" control strategies that we developed, in which the PDE model is used in an optimization problem to compute a priori the robot controllers or design parameters that will yield a desired spatial distribution of activity. We also proved new results on the controllability of swarms described by ADR PDEs under realistic conditions of a closed environment and bounded controllers.

In addition, we designed new mathematical and computational methods that use limited feedback to characterize the environment or estimate the swarm's progress, enabling redesign of the robot controllers to improve the collective performance. This feedback includes external observations of the swarm, if possible, and data collected by the robots that is processed offline or on the robots in real-time. We developed novel techniques for reconstructing scalar fields from data on a subset of the swarm distribution; mapping the geometry of the boundary or interior of a region of interest using only robots' encounter times with the region; and attaining a target swarm task allocation with stochastic task-switching that stops once the allocation is reached.

Finally, we synthesized new control strategies that use implicit robot coordination and minimal global information to reshape a swarm and guide its movement. We designed communication-free schemes in which one or two "leader" robots with localization capabilities control the formation of a swarm of unlocalized robots with limited sensing or confine and herd the robots along a trajectory.

This project provided funding for one Ph.D. student, who plans to graduate in Spring 2019.  He will then begin a postdoctoral research position in applied mathematics at UCLA, supervised by co-PI Andrea Bertozzi, where he will expand on the research conducted during this project. The research results have been disseminated through journal articles, conference publications and presentations, and invited talks. The PI and co-PI organized a minisymposium on project topics at the 2015 SIAM Conference on Analysis of Partial Differential Equations.

The project also provided research opportunities for 10 undergraduate students, 5 in PI Berman's lab and 5 in co-PI Bertozzi's lab, who co-authored 2 peer-reviewed conference publications. Four undergraduates in PI Berman's lab (1 female, 2 underrepresented minorities, and 1 first-generation college student) contributed to the project goals involving multi-robot experimentation by designing components for small mobile robots called "Pheeno," developed in PI Berman's lab, and programming the robots for different tasks. Five undergraduates participated in a summer REU program at UCLA organized by co-PI Bertozzi, where they implemented a swarm coverage strategy developed during the project using a small robot built in the lab.

  • Modeling the population dynamics of a robotic swarm as an advection-diffusion-reaction partial differential equation, we established controllability results for this model and developed a method for computing swarm parameters that guarantee coverage within a certain error from a target distribution.
    Fangbo Zhang, Andrea L. Bertozzi, Karthik Elamvazhuthi, and Spring Berman (2018). "Performance Bounds on Spatial Coverage Tasks by Stochastic Robotic Swarms." IEEE Transactions on Automatic Control, 63(6):1563-1578.
    Copyrighted
    Spring Berman
    Control of stochastic coverage and task allocation by robotic swarms using macroscopic models of swarm population dynamics
  • We designed feedback control laws that stabilize a robotic swarm to a target distribution among a set of states, given that the robots? states evolve according to an interacting system of continuous time Markov chains. The controllers require the robots to know the population in their current state.
    Karthik Elamvazhuthi, Shiba Biswal, and Spring Berman (2018). "Mean-Field Stabilization of Robotic Swarms to Probability Distributions with Disconnected Supports." 2018 Annual American Control Conference (ACC), pp. 885-892.
    Copyrighted
    Spring Berman
    Stochastic task allocation in robotic swarms using feedback on local robot populations
  • We developed a framework for controlling a robotic swarm with stochastic behaviors to achieve a target spatial distribution of activity, such as pollination by robotic bees. We formulated this problem as a PDE-constrained optimization problem, which we solved using techniques from optimal control.
    Karthik Elamvazhuthi and Spring Berman (2015). "Optimal Control of Stochastic Coverage Strategies for Robotic Swarms." 2015 IEEE International Conference on Robotics and Automation (ICRA), pp. 1822-1829.
    Copyrighted
    Spring Berman
    Optimal control of stochastic coverage strategies for robotic swarms
  • We developed a method to control coverage by a diffusing swarm of robots that take local measurements of a scalar field. The diffusion coefficient is chosen to depend only on the robots' measurements to ensure that the swarm density converges to a function that is proportional to the scalar field.
    K. Elamvazhuthi, et al. (2016). "Coverage and field estimation on bounded domains by diffusive swarms." IEEE Conf. Decision & Control; H. Li, et al. (2017). "Decentralized stochastic control of robotic swarm density: Theory, simulation, and experiment." IEEE/RSJ Int'l. Conf. Intell. Robots & Systems
    Copyrighted
    Spring Berman
    Achieving a swarm coverage density that is proportional to a scalar field
  • We developed a framework for controlling a robotic swarm with stochastic behaviors to gather data for mapping a region of interest. We frame the mapping problem as a convex optimization problem whose solution represents the region as a coefficient in a PDE model of the swarm population dynamics.
    Karthik Elamvazhuthi, Hendrik Kuiper, and Spring Berman (2018). "PDE-Based Optimization for Stochastic Mapping and Coverage Strategies using Robotic Swarms." Automatica, 95:356-367.
    Copyrighted
    Spring Berman
    Optimization for stochastic mapping strategies using robotic swarms
